description: Function Health biomarker integration schema for personalized nutrition optimization

about_function_health.service: Comprehensive lab testing with 100+ biomarkers for preventive health
about_function_health.frequency: Quarterly testing recommended for tracking trends

nutrient_status.description: Direct measurement of nutrient levels in blood - most accurate way to assess deficiencies

if_below_40: Add fatty fish (salmon, sardines, mackerel) 4x per week
Increase healthy fats with meals for absorption

markers.note: Levels 200-400 can still cause neurological symptoms

if_below_500: Add liver 1-2x per week (highest B12 source - 59mcg/100g)
For vegans: supplementation required (food sources insufficient)

if_below_10: Avoid synthetic folic acid - use natural folate sources

markers.note: Better indicator than serum iron; tracks long-term status

if_low: Add red meat (heme iron) 3-4x per week
Include liver 1x per week (highest bioavailable iron)
Add vitamin C with all plant iron sources
Separate calcium supplements from iron-rich meals by 2+ hours
if_high: Reduce red meat and liver intake
Increase tea consumption with meals (tannins reduce absorption)

markers.note: RBC magnesium better than serum (serum doesn't reflect intracellular status)

if_below_6: Add leafy greens (cooked spinach, Swiss chard)

if_below_90: Add oysters 1-2x per week (78mg/100g - highest source)

markers.note: Measures EPA+DHA in red blood cell membranes - best marker for omega-3 status

if_below_8: Add wild fatty fish 4-5x per week (salmon, sardines, mackerel)
Reduce omega-6 sources (seed oils, grain-fed meat)
Include walnuts as plant source (supplement, not replacement)

metabolic_health.description: Indicators of blood sugar control and metabolic function

if_above_85: Add cinnamon to meals (improves insulin sensitivity)
Prioritize low-glycemic carbs (sweet potato, quinoa, legumes)
Increase protein at breakfast (stabilizes blood sugar)
Include apple cider vinegar before carb-heavy meals

markers.note: 3-month average of blood sugar - better than single glucose test

meal_plan_adjustments.if_above_5_3: Same as fasting glucose recommendations - focus on blood sugar stability

markers.note: Elevated insulin appears YEARS before glucose rises - early warning sign

if_above_5: Prioritize protein and fat over carbohydrates

cardiovascular_health.description: Heart disease risk markers - focus on advanced lipid testing

markers.note: Best single predictor of cardiovascular risk - measures particle number

if_above_80: Increase omega-3 intake (fatty fish 4-5x per week)
Reduce saturated fat from poor sources (grain-fed meat, processed foods)
Focus on monounsaturated fats (olive oil, avocados)

markers.note: More important than LDL cholesterol amount - particle number matters
Measures systemic inflammation - predictor of heart disease and chronic illness

if_above_0_5: Include turmeric with black pepper daily
Add fermented foods (gut health reduces inflammation)
Eliminate refined sugars and seed oils

markers.note: Elevated = increased cardiovascular risk and poor methylation

if_above_7: Increase folate-rich foods (liver, leafy greens, legumes)
Add B12 sources (meat, fish, eggs) - critical for lowering homocysteine
Ensure all B vitamins are adequate (work together for methylation)
Consider MTHFR gene testing (affects folate metabolism)

thyroid_function.description: Thyroid hormones regulate metabolism, energy, weight

markers.note: Higher TSH = thyroid struggling to produce hormones
Most important thyroid hormone - active form

if_suboptimal: Add selenium (Brazil nuts, fish) - required for T4→T3 conversion
Include zinc (oysters, red meat) - supports thyroid function
Ensure adequate protein (amino acids needed for thyroid hormones)
Avoid excessive raw cruciferous if low thyroid

if_low: Ensure adequate healthy fats (cholesterol is precursor)
Reduce sugar and refined carbs (insulin impacts testosterone)

markers.note: Stress hormone - should be highest in morning

if_high: Add vitamin C rich foods (stress increases need)

personalization_engine.description: How to use biomarker data to personalize meal plans

workflow.action: User uploads Function Health lab results (or manually enters key biomarkers)
workflow.data_extracted: Vitamin D, B12, Ferritin, Magnesium, Omega-3 Index, HbA1c, hs-CRP, etc.

workflow.action: App identifies deficiencies and suboptimal ranges
workflow.logic: Compare against functional ranges (not standard lab ranges)

priority_levels.critical: Below functional minimum - needs immediate attention
priority_levels.suboptimal: In acceptable range but below optimal
priority_levels.optimal: No dietary intervention needed, maintain current intake

workflow.action: Adjust meal plan to address deficiencies
adjustments: Increase frequency of specific nutrient-dense foods
Add targeted recipes (e.g., liver for B12/iron)
Modify preparation methods (e.g., cook spinach to reduce oxalates if iron is low)
Adjust meal timing (e.g., avoid tea with iron-rich meals if ferritin is low)
Suggest food combinations for synergy (e.g., vitamin C with plant iron)

workflow.goal: Move all biomarkers into optimal functional ranges

example_personalization.scenario: User with low vitamin D (28 ng/mL) and low ferritin (22 ng/mL)

add: Wild salmon 4x per week (replace chicken in 2 dinners)
Pastured eggs at every breakfast (increase from 2 to 3)
Cast iron cooking for all meals
modify: Add bell peppers (vitamin C) to all iron-rich meals
Boil spinach and discard water (reduce oxalates)
Move tea consumption to 2+ hours after meals
remove: Calcium-rich foods at same meal as iron sources (separate by 2+ hours)

personalized_adjustments.expected_improvement: Retest in 3 months - expect vitamin D >40 ng/mL, ferritin >50 ng/mL
